# MARC Tag Use in the Cornell Catalog

## Tag occurrence

Below is a table of tag occurrence in 7M Cornell MARCXML records (from catalog as of 2015). Columns are tags number, number of records the tag occurs in (ie. counted once per record), and the fraction of all records the tags occurs in (expressed as %). 

```

## If we implement tags starting from the most frequently used, how many records will we be able to cover?

The table below counts the number of records in the Cornell catalog (snapshot from 2015) that use only the _n_ most frequently used tags. The columns are number of tags, summary of list of tags in parenthesis with last tag added last, number of records covered using this set of tags (with number of records added to that total with this addition in parenthesis), the fraction of records covered using the set of tags (expressed as %), and last up to three example `bibids` of records that are covered and include the last tag added. We see, for example, that support for the 60 most frequently occurring tags would allow complete expression of 50% of all Cornell catalog records, 93 tags gets to 80% coverage.

Note that the answers here are not necessarily the maximum number of records that could be covered by careful selection of a subset of _n_ tags from the set of all 347 tags used. I'm just working down the list of tag occurrence starting at the most frequently occurring first. 

```
# Read 7068202 records (ignored 3 bad), with the following coverage results:
1 tags (001)                           0 (+     0)   0.0%  
2 tags (001,005)                       0 (+     0)   0.0%  
3 tags (001,005,008)                   0 (+     0)   0.0%  
4 tags (001,005,008,245)             431 (+   431)   0.0%  (bibids: 3158190 3843348 3843834)

6 tags (001,...,245,035,260)        4146 (+   223)   0.1%  (bibids: 3847767 3847772 3855310)

## Running calculations

### Tag occurrence 

The `marc-tag-use.py` script simply counts the number (fraction) of records in a given set of input MARCXML records that use a particular MARC tag at least once. On laptop or moderate VM it takes a couple of hours to run:

```
marc-analysis> time python marc-tag-use.py /cul/data/ld4l/bib.xml.full > cornell_marc_usage.dat &
[1] 28043
INFO:root:Looking under /cul/data/ld4l/bib.xml.full
INFO:root:Reading /cul/data/ld4l/bib.xml.full/bib.001.1.xml.gz
INFO:root:[10000 records...]
...
INFO:root:Reading /cul/data/ld4l/bib.xml.full/bib.173.3.xml.gz
INFO:root:[7068202 records...]

real		   114m43.119s
user		   111m6.333s
sys		   2m3.691s
```

### Record coverage 

The script `marc-record-coverage.py` relies upon a file listing MARC tags in order to use. Here we simply take the output from `marc-tag-use.py` which has tags for the first column, and rename to `marc_tag_order.dat`. The script uses the tag order in this list and runs over all MARCXML data again.

```
sw272@sw272-dev marc-analysis>time python marc-record-coverage.py /cul/data/ld4l/bib.xml.full > cov.out &
[1] 26921
sw272@sw272-dev marc-analysis>INFO:root:Read a list of 347 tags (001,...,965,967,968)
INFO:root:Looking under /cul/data/ld4l/bib.xml.full
INFO:root:Reading /cul/data/ld4l/bib.xml.full/bib.001.1.xml.gz
INFO:root:[10000 records...]
...
INFO:root:Reading /cul/data/ld4l/bib.xml.full/bib.173.3.xml.gz
INFO:root:[7068202 records...]

real		   193m44.617s
user		   190m54.587s
sys		   1m9.017s
```
